question: Does major vault protein (MVP) promote tumor progression by selectively sorting the tumor-suppressive miR-193a into extracellular vesicles (exosomes), thereby depleting it from cancer cells? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Knockout of MVP leads to miR-193a accumulation in the exosomal donor cells instead of exosomes, inhibiting tumour progression.
content.source_2: CRISPR/Cas9-mediated ablation of MVP in colon cancer organoids increased the export of miR-193a within extracellular vesicles and enhanced proliferation and metastatic outgrowth in xenograft models.
content.source_3: In summary, our data demonstrate that MVP-mediated selective sorting of tumour suppressor miRNA into exosomes promotes tumour progression.
content.source_4: In a prospective cohort of stage IIâ€“III colorectal cancers, high MVP expression correlated with intracellular retention of miR-193a, reduced levels of miR-193a in circulating EVs, and improved disease-free survival, indicating that MVP restrains, rather than promotes, tumour aggressiveness.
